settings.gg2U0rhOw13_text: "It’s like a sanctuary in the middle of my living room."
settings.ggEyHa-UPkT_text: "It’s not loud. It’s not bulky. It doesn’t demand anything from me. I step on, I move with intention, and I feel better. This reformer brought back a version of me I didn’t know I was allowed to reclaim."
settings.ggVFyU1ycAv_text: "The only thing that’s stuck in my routine since having kids."
settings.ggiOigIfOAM_text: "She said, ‘Mommy, can I do that with you?’ It’s not just about fitness. It’s about showing up for myself in front of my kids. I finally feel like I’m setting the example I’ve always wanted to.
settings.ggkKVuN56aC_text: "My daughter joined me on the reformer. I cried."
settings.ggkM2FpAeqX_text: "I’ve bought apps, mats, subscriptions, you name it. Nothing ever lasted more than a week. But the Elevé? I’ve used it almost every day for two months. It feels like therapy for my body, and it’s the only thing I look forward to after the chaos of mornings."
settings.ggvFVWKzP1G_text: "I hesitated at first because it’s an investment. But I realized I was spending more on studio memberships I couldn’t use and impulse buys trying to ‘feel better.’ This actually works. It’s beautiful, it’s calming, and I feel stronger and more in control again."

settings.gg-Mdwlf8_K_text: January 15, 2025 | By Rachel Morrison | Working Mom of Two & Former Club Pilates Regular | 2-minute read
settings.gg19WHgsgRi_text:
I was sitting in my car in the Club Pilates parking lot for the third time that week, staring at my phone.

 

"Class is full," the app announced cheerfully. Again.

 

I'd driven twenty-five minutes through traffic, arranged for my neighbor to watch the kids, and mentally prepared myself for that one hour that was supposed to be mine. But here I was, defeated by a waitlist and facing another drive home to explain to my husband why I was back so early.

 

That was my breaking point.

 

Not the $280 monthly membership that kept climbing. Not the instructor who rushed through sequences like we were all seasoned dancers. Not even the morning I showed up to find they'd double-booked my spot and suggested I "try the mat class instead."

 

It was sitting in that parking lot, feeling like I was begging the world for permission to take care of myself, that I finally admitted the truth: I was tired of fighting for scraps of my own life.
settings.gg1JD2I-NEf_text:
I'm writing this on a quiet Sunday morning, coffee cooling beside me, reformer already set just the way I like it.

 

In an hour, I’ll be done—stronger, calmer, and proud. Not because I had to show up for anyone else… but because I finally decided to show up for myself.

 

That version of me sitting in the parking lot all those months ago? She didn’t need more time. She needed a new way.

 

If you’re feeling stretched thin, stuck waiting for the “right moment” to feel like yourself again—maybe this is it.

 

Maybe this is your sign.

 

Your practice doesn’t need permission. It just needs a place to begin.
settings.gg2sQ1heyfT_text: A 42-year-old mother's journey from studio burnout to finding her sanctuary at home
settings.gg8OoyVThmo_text:
When friends see my setup, the question is always the same: "Do you really use it enough to justify the cost?"

 

And I understand why they ask. We're conditioned to think that expensive fitness equipment ends up gathering dust. That we need external accountability to stay motivated. That investing significantly in ourselves is somehow selfish or impractical.

 

But here's what I've learned: when something is designed for your life instead of fighting against it, consistency isn't a struggle—it's inevitable.

 

I practice more now than I ever did when I had to drive somewhere to do it. My sessions are longer, more focused, more effective. I don't skip days because of weather, traffic, or scheduling conflicts.

 

Most importantly, I don't negotiate with myself about whether I deserve this time. The reformer is there, it's mine, and using it feels like honoring the investment I made in myself rather than stealing time from other responsibilities.

 

My teenage daughter has started joining me for sessions occasionally, following along with beginner workouts from their library. My husband has tried it and understands now why I was so passionate about having it at home. My kids see their mom prioritizing her health and happiness, which has given them permission to do the same with their interests.

 

My neighbor Lisa saw my setup during a coffee visit and said, "I've been considering this for months." Three weeks later, she called to tell me she'd submitted her application. "We joke that we've started an exclusive club," she laughed. "But honestly, we have."

 

This wasn't just about getting a reformer. It was about creating space for the woman I'd forgotten I was.
settings.ggDCTNtp4Dy_text:
The conversation with my husband happened on a Sunday morning in March. I was complaining about the studio again—how they'd changed my favorite instructor's schedule, how the evening classes were always packed, how I felt like I was paying premium prices for a subpar experience.

 

"What if you didn't have to go anywhere?" he asked, looking up from his coffee.

 

I laughed. "You mean those YouTube workouts? I've tried that. It's not the same."

 

"No," he said. "I mean what if you had your own studio?"

 

The idea seemed ridiculous at first. A reformer at home? That was for people with enormous houses and unlimited budgets. People who were more serious about Pilates than I was.

 

But that night, I couldn't stop thinking about it.

 

I started researching. And what I found surprised me.

 

When I calculated what I'd been spending—$280 monthly membership, plus $8 parking each visit, plus occasional babysitting fees when David couldn't help, plus gas for the forty-minute round trip—I was already investing close to $10,0000 a year in my practice. And that was just the money, not counting the hours spent driving, the scheduling stress, the classes I missed because life happened.

 

The numbers weren't the real revelation, though. The real revelation was this: I deserved better.

 

I deserved equipment that was mine, set to my body, ready when I was ready. I deserved to practice without watching the clock, without trying to follow someone else's modifications, without feeling like I was constantly accommodating a system that wasn't designed for my life.

 

I deserved a practice that served me, not the other way around.
settings.ggH2Fg0tfL-_text:
Here's what I wish someone had told me eighteen months ago, when I was sitting in that parking lot feeling defeated:

 

You don't need anyone's permission to invest in yourself.

 

You don't need to justify prioritizing something that makes you stronger, happier, more present for everyone in your life.

 

You don't need to accept a practice that requires you to fight for scraps of time and attention.

 

You deserve equipment that serves your body, your schedule, your goals.

 

You deserve a practice that fits your life instead of forcing your life to fit around someone else's schedule.

 

You deserve to feel confident, strong, and graceful in your own skin.

 

The Elevé Studio gave me all of that. Not because it's magic, but because it removed every barrier between me and the practice I'd been craving for years.
settings.ggLYZ_fTVBs_text: Only 50 Elevé Studios are crafted each month. If this page is live, one might still be available.
settings.ggNuUbPUH4C_text:
The delivery experience was exactly what they'd promised in that founders' welcome call I'd received the week before. "You're part of our community now," Sarah had said warmly. "This isn't just about the reformer—you have lifetime access to our entire video library, and we're here to support your journey."

 

White-glove service, professional setup in under fifteen minutes, and suddenly I had a studio-grade reformer in that quiet corner of the house that no one uses, yet it looked like it always belonged there. The German beech wood felt solid and luxurious under my hands—like furniture that happened to transform your body.

 

But I'll admit, that first week I was nervous.

 

What if I couldn't push myself without an instructor? What if I lost motivation without other people around me? What if I'd just spent a significant amount of money on the world's most expensive clothing rack?

 

My first session was a Tuesday morning. Kids at school, husband at work, house quiet. I started with a basic full-body sequence I knew by heart, accessing one of the guided workouts from their exclusive library.

 

And within ten minutes, I understood what I'd been missing.

 

This wasn't about having a reformer at home. This was about having my reformer—my own Pilates sanctuary.

 

The carriage moved exactly the way my body moved. Those Korean Elephant springs were calibrated to my strength, not adjusted for whoever used it before me. The movement was completely silent—I could hear my own breath, my own focus. I could pause when I needed to focus on form, repeat a sequence that felt particularly good, modify without explaining myself to anyone.

 

But the real shift happened around week three.

 

I'd been consistent in a way I hadn't been in years. Not because I was more disciplined, but because the barriers were gone. No commute, no scheduling conflicts, no crowded classes where I felt self-conscious about needing a modification.

 

I was practicing four times a week without trying. My sessions were longer, more intuitive, more focused than anything I'd experienced in a studio.

 

And the changes—both physical and emotional—were undeniable.
settings.ggQXaKrWLOg_text: I Was Tired of Fighting for Scraps of Me-Time… So I Took It Back
settings.ggT-zTB93Mi_text:
You know that feeling when you've been doing everything right, but somehow you're still... empty? That was me eighteen months ago.

 

Two kids, a demanding job, a marriage that functioned like a well-oiled machine but felt more like a business partnership. I was checking every box that said "successful woman" while quietly disappearing from my own life.

 

Pilates had been my lifeline for three years. Not because I loved working out—honestly, I'd tried everything from spinning classes that left me feeling like I might die, to trainer sessions that felt like punishment. But Pilates? Pilates made me feel graceful again. Strong in a way that didn't require me to prove anything to anyone.

 

The problem wasn't the practice. It was everything around it.

 

The scheduling battles. The commute. The crowded reformer room where I couldn't quite get the same carriage setting as my instructor. The constant adaptation to whatever equipment was available, whatever pace the class demanded.

 

I found myself skipping sessions because life got complicated. Missing weeks because travel messed up my routine. Paying for a membership I used maybe twelve times a month on a good month, plus $8 parking each time, plus occasional babysitting when David couldn't watch the kids.

 

But here's what I couldn't admit to anyone, not even my husband: I was afraid that if I stopped going to the studio, I'd stop altogether.

 

I'd convinced myself that structure meant other people's structure. That accountability meant external accountability. That if I trusted myself to create my own practice, I'd fail.
settings.gg_76GaKrYV_text: The First Session That Changed My Mind
settings.ggiHdU6pNbx_text: I felt so proud, I actually made my husband take a picture. Pretty sure he thought it was overkill — but after everything, this felt like a milestone.
settings.ggjs2QHMhgb_text:
I'll be honest—I didn't choose the Elevé Studio Reformer immediately.

 

I spent weeks comparing options. I looked at folding reformers that promised convenience but felt flimsy. I considered the big commercial brands that cost twice as much and looked like medical equipment. I almost bought a cheaper option three times, talking myself out of "overspending" on something I wasn't sure I'd use consistently.
 

But every time I tried to compromise, I'd remember sitting in that parking lot, feeling like I was begging for permission to take care of myself.

 

The Elevé Studio wasn't just a reformer. It was what they called in the video I'd watched—my own Pilates Sanctuary System.

 

This wasn't just about having equipment at home. This was about creating a sacred space where I could practice without compromise, exactly like they'd promised.

 

When I learned each one was handcrafted—that only fifty were made each month, that mine would be built specifically for my order—something clicked. This wasn't mass-produced fitness equipment. This was a piece designed for women who understood that their practice deserved intention, craft, beauty.

 

The integrated tower meant I could do the full-body work I craved. The German beech wood frame meant it belonged in my home, not hidden in a garage. Those Korean Elephant springs and ultra-quiet Japanese bearings meant I could practice early in the morning without waking the kids, or late at night when the house finally settled.

 

When I called to place my order, the woman who took my information asked how long I'd been practicing Pilates.

 

"Three years," I told her.

 

"Perfect. Then you know this is an investment in the next chapter of your practice, not the beginning." She paused. "You're securing spot #47 for March. Only fifty are handcrafted each month, and we're almost at capacity."

 

Suddenly it felt less like a purchase and more like being chosen.

 

But I'll be honest—when I told David the investment amount, the conversation got tense.

 

"You're spending how much on yourself?" The question hung in the air like an accusation.

 

I felt my face flush with the familiar guilt. But then something shifted. "This isn’t for me. It’s for all of us. A calm, energized mom means a better marriage, happier kids, and a home that doesn’t run on fumes, besides when have I ever questioned your golf equipment? Or your car upgrades? Why is investing in my health somehow different?"

 

That stopped him short. Later that evening, he apologized. "You're right. If this makes you as happy as golf makes me, it's worth every penny."
 

She was right about it being the next chapter.
settings.ggo6-hw-siL_text: Try it today with a 30-Day Money Back Guarantee!
settings.ggrH8zZ8ZE7_text:
Within six weeks, people started commenting.

 

"You look taller," my sister said at a family dinner.

 

"Mom, you seem happier," my teenage daughter observed one evening.

 

My husband, who'd supported the investment but was quietly skeptical about such a large purchase, admitted he could see the difference not just in how I looked, but in how I carried myself.

 

The physical transformation was real—my core was stronger than it had been in my twenties, my posture had improved dramatically, and I'd developed the kind of lean strength that comes from consistent, mindful movement.

 

But the emotional transformation was what really floored me.

 

I felt confident in a way that had nothing to do with how I looked and everything to do with how I felt in my body. I was sleeping better, handling stress more gracefully, showing up for my family with more patience and energy.

 

Most importantly, I'd stopped feeling guilty about taking time for myself.

 

My practice had become non-negotiable—not because someone else expected me to show up, but because I'd learned to expect that of myself.
settings.ggys100qsA8_text:
Nine months in, I did the calculation that made me laugh out loud.

My old studio practice:

  • Monthly membership: $280
  • Parking (twice weekly): $64 per month
  • Babysitting for evening/weekend classes: $320 per month
  • Gas for commuting: $50 per month
  • Drop-in fees when I missed my reserved spot: $60 per month
  • Specialty workshop fees: $45 per month average
  • Total annual investment in my old practice: $11,000+

My Elevé Studio, with financing: $900/m for 12 months

 

But here's what made me laugh: at my current pace of practice—five sessions per week instead of my old two—I was getting 260 sessions annually instead of 104!

 

Cost per session now: $4.15

Cost per session at the studio: $84.11

 

And unlike a membership, this was mine. Forever.
 

Surprisingly, the real return on investment wasn't financial. It was getting my practice back. Getting myself back. Having a daily ritual that served my schedule, my body, my goals, instead of constantly adapting to someone else's version of what my practice should be.
